Scheme 1 The Glaser–Hay reaction [34]. Fig. 1 Phenyl-acetylene 1; 4-methylphenyl-acetylene 2; 4-methoxyphenyl-acetylene 3; 4-dimethylaminophenyl-acetylene 4; 4-fluorophenyl-acetylene 5; 4-trifluoromethylphenyl-acetylene 6; 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol 7; 1-ethynyl-1-cyclohexanol 8. Fig. 2 TEM images for HAp (a); Cu–HAp (b); the scale bar is 50nm. Fig. 3 XRD powder pattern of HAp and Cu–HAp. The short vertical lines below the profile curves mark the positions of all Bragg reflections of the apatite crystal structure. Fig. 4 FTIR spectrum (400–4000cm−1) of Cu–HAp. Fig. 5 Diynes 9–16 obtained from terminal alkynes 1–8. Table 1 Yields% on 9–16 diynes after 72h of reaction. M. Curie, Institut Parisien de Chimie Moleculaire, 4, Place Jussieu, Case 42, 75005 Paris, France. Tel.: +33 1 44 27 30 59. Graphical abstract The oxidative Glaser–Hay coupling reaction of terminal alkynes is a very important reaction in organic chemistry to achieve the synthesis of diyne compounds. In general the reaction is performed under homogeneous conditions using Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts in the presence of a reagent such as tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA), which can bind to copper ions, an organic base and dioxygen. Although this reaction is known for a long time, the mechanism is still under discussion. Pursuing our investigations on the use of apatites as catalysts for organic reactions we highlight in this work how it is possible to catalyze the Glaser–Hay reaction under heterogeneous conditions using a Cu-modified hydroxyapatite (Cu–HAp). With several para-substituted phenyl-acetylenes and alkynols we show that Cu–HAp acts as catalyst for CC coupling reactions leading to diyne derivatives in high yields without using auxiliary chelating molecules and organic bases. These heterogeneous conditions allow an easy recovery of the catalyst and simplify the purification work-up. Keywords Apatites Glaser–Hay reaction Copper Alkynes 1 Introduction Among the properties of apatites, a mineral involved in a large number of applications in chemistry and biochemistry [1–3], their catalytic properties are emerging in different fields of organic synthesis [4–7]. For example, Sebti et al. described the use of hydroxyapatites (HAp) and/or fluorapatites (FAp) in the Knoevenagel reaction [8] as well as the addition of thiolates to conjugated enones [9]. Other reactions catalyzed by apatites are described in the literature: Hydroformylation [10,11], Diels–Alder [12], oxidation of organo-silanes [13], Friedel–Crafts [14], racemization of secondary alcohols [15], N-arylation of imidazoles [16,17], dihydroxylation of double bonds [18]. We have recently shown that hydroxyapatites are good catalysts for the Michael CC bond formation under solvent free conditions and highlighted the role of the basic properties of their surfaces in the catalytic process [19]. Modified apatites have been obtained either by substitution of Ca2+ ions or upon partial dissolution and re-precipitation of the apatite in a new rich phase with another cation such as Ru3+, La3+, Pd2+, Rh3+. These materials showed also ability to catalyze organic reactions mainly the oxidation of alcohols [20,21]. Recently, copper modified apatites were described as catalysts in cycloaddition reactions [22,23]. We have discovered that apatites themselves can serve as catalysts due to the peculiar acid–base properties of their surfaces [19]. In this way, we have systematically studied the catalytic properties of modified and not-modified apatites. In this paper we describe the synthesis of a Cu(II)-modified hydroxyapatite Cu–HAp and its ability to catalyze the formation of diyne compounds through a homo-coupling reaction. Such compounds received interest because of their wide range of applications in organic materials and molecular electronics [24,25]. Also, the 1,3-diyne moiety can be found in various natural products [26] or in pharmaceuticals with antitumor [27] or anti-inflammatory properties [28]. In this context, the CC homo-coupling reaction obtained by the very well known Glaser reaction [29] in which two terminal alkynes lead to a diyne compound is shown in Scheme 1 . Some recent reviews describe the importance of this reaction in organic synthesis [30–32]. This homo-coupling is usually performed under homogeneous conditions using Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts in the presence of a chelating agent (the most efficient is TMEDA) and an amine as organic base, in the presence of dioxygen as oxidant [33,34]. Some recent works reported the relative efficiency of different chelating agents acting as ligand for the copper ions as well as different bases, usually amines, in the Glaser or Glaser–Hay reactions [35,36]. More recently, Sharifi et al. [37] described a homo-coupling reaction of terminal alkynes on alumina assisted by microwave irradiation. Nevertheless, under these conditions the use of morpholine acting as a base is necessary to perform the reaction. We note that copper supported catalysts are currently attracting much attention, for instance copper–aluminium based nanocomposites were recently reported as excellent heterogeneous catalysts in the so-called A3 coupling reactions leading to propargylic amines [38]. Considering the fact that surfaces of apatites have acidic (PO2H) and basic (OH) sites [39,40] (the surface properties are related to the preparation mode of the material and especially correlated to the Ca/P ratio [41,42]) and their ability to exchange Ca2+ by Cu2+ ions [43], we decided to synthesize a Cu2+ modified apatite and explore its aptitude to catalyze the homo-coupling reaction using terminal alkynes as starting material, namely: phenyl-alkynes 1–6 possessing para-substituted donor 2–4 or withdrawing groups 5, 6 and two alkynols 7, 8. These alkynes are represented in Fig. 1 . 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalyst The Cu–HAp was obtained as a result of Cu2+ ions sorption from a Cu(CH3CO2)2 aqueous solution with HAp (Ca/P=1.57). Under these conditions one can assume that a small amount of Ca2+ is exchanged by Cu2+ ions (found: 6.1% Cu weight). The TEM observations and X-ray powder diffraction are in agreement with these results. The TEM pictures (Fig. 2 ) reveal no modification of morphology in the HAp crystallites and no other crystallites with different morphologies, indicating that no new phase appears during the reaction between HAp and the copper salt. In contrast, new phase formations were observed when an HAp reacts with ruthenium(III) or lanthanum(III) salts [21–44]. The HAp and Cu–HAp appear as elongated nanoparticles whose dimensions are approximately 30nm in length and 15nm in width. The analysis of HAp and Cu–HAp X-ray powder patterns (Fig. 3 ) shows that both do not exhibit diffraction lines other than those due to the apatite crystal structure (space group P63/m). In other words, no another phase have been identified from the XRD pattern in agreement with the TEM picture analysis. The intensities of the diffraction peaks and the refined cell parameters are the same (a =9.434Å; c =6.881Å) taking into account the standard deviations. The broadening of the diffraction peaks is different for the hk0 lines and 00 ℓ lines indicating clearly the anisotropic morphology of the crystallites. The Scherrer's equation leads to a size of the crystallites of 15×27nm approximately for HAp and Cu–HAp in agreement with the TEM images. Their IR spectra have the same pattern corresponding to the classical spectra of a well-crystallized HAp containing small amount of CO3 2− ions (Fig. 4 ) [45]. 2.2 Homo-coupling reactions Refluxing alkynes 1–8 in CH3CN in the presence of Cu–HAp leads to diynes 9–16 (Fig. 5 ). Compounds 9–16 were characterized by 1H and 13C NMR, mass and FT-IR spectroscopies. In FT-IR, the signal corresponding to the C≡CH triple bond disappears with the formation of the homo-coupling compounds. Yields on diynes compounds 9–16 after 72h of reaction are presented in Table 1 . We checked that no reaction occurred either in the absence of Cu–HAp or in the presence of not modified HAp as catalyst. Using the filtrate of a 48h refluxing Cu–HAp in CH3CN has not showed any catalytic activity, which indicates that no copper leaching occurs under our reaction conditions. Furthermore the homocoupling products were obtained in modest to excellent yields (21–99%) without any by-product. The efficiency of the reaction is depending on the donor or acceptor character of the para-substituent of the starting alkyne, so that complete reaction of 1, 5 and 6 can be achieved within 18h. In these cases the Cu–HAp catalyst can be reused, after simple filtration (three cycles), without significant decrease of efficiency. Moreover the fact that Cu–HAp promoted the homo-coupling reaction without an auxiliary base, highlights the basic role of the apatite surface towards the first step of the reaction consisting of the abstraction of the acidic alkyne proton. This step is easier according to the acidity of this proton, which is enhanced by using electron withdrawing groups at the para-position of the aromatic ring of substituted phenyl-alkynes. Hay [34] noticed that: “Most copper(II) salts are inactive as catalysts” but, “When a bidentate ligand such as TMEDA is used, the reaction is considerably faster”. In our case, the Cu(II) present on the surface of the apatite is bounded through the phosphate anions of the apatite. Therefore, the apatite is not only the base, but also plays the role of ligand for the copper ions located at its surface. Interestingly, the absence of such organic bases and tetra-amino compounds is advantageous for the (i) purification step of the final diynes and (ii) the recovery of the Cu–HAp catalyst that can be reused. 3 Conclusions After the early demonstration that apatites are good catalysts for the Michael reaction, we provide the efficiency of a new copper modified apatite as catalyst. In this work we demonstrated that CuHAp can be used under heterogeneous conditions for the homo-coupling of terminal alkynes. The corresponding diynes are obtained in moderate to excellent yields depending on the acidity of the alkynyl proton of the starting material. These results illustrate that apatite surfaces are able, due to their acid–base properties, not only to interact with organic molecules, but also to be the location of CC coupling reactions. Contrary to homogeneous conditions, the catalytic process occurs in the absence of an external base and of chelating reagent. The heterogeneous character of the catalyst used, facilitates the purification of the final diynes and allows a simple recovery of the catalyst. Our current investigations are focusing on the use of palladium and/or copper modified hydroxyapatites in the Sonogashira reaction as described in a closely related work though with different types of catalysts [52]. 4 Experimental 4.1 General All alkynes 1–8 starting materials were used as received from the commercial suppliers. CH3CN was purified by distillation under CaH2. Column chromatographies were performed on SiO2 using pentane or pentane/ethyl acetate as eluents. 1H (300.13MHz) and 13C (75.5MHz) NMR solution spectra were obtained with a Bruker Avance II 300 spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were recorded from pure products using a Bruker Tensor 27 equipped with a diamond ATR setup in the range 400–4000cm−1. Chemical composition of apatites was obtained using standard chemical methods for phosphorus and calcium. The content of Cu2+ ions in solution was detected by titration with ethylenediaminotetraacetic acid (EDTA) (0.01M), indicator 1% peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN) solution, before and after reaction with apatite. The specific surface area (SSA) measurements were performed by the BET method (adsorptive gas N2, carrier gas He, heating temperature 150°C) using sorptometer EMS-53 and KELVIN 1040/1042 software (Costech International). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Siemens D5000 diffractometer mounted in a Bragg Brentano configuration, equipped with a copper anode and a secondary monochromator (λKα1 =1.5406Å; λKα2 =1.5444Å). The 2θ angular resolution was 0.04°. The diffraction patterns were scanned over the 2θ range 20–80. X-ray powder patterns were firstly analyzed using the software EVA [46,47]. The Kα2 components of the diffraction lines were subtracted and the positions of diffraction peaks were then carefully measured in order to refine the cell parameters using the software CHECKCELL [48]. The background corrected powder X-ray patterns are then analyzed using the FULLPROF suite software [49,50]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were performed with a JEOL 100CXII transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 100kV. The sample drops were deposited and dried on carbon-coated copper grids. 4.2 Synthesis and identification of the Cu–HAp HAp was synthesized by adding Ca(NO3)2 and (NH4)2HPO4 solutions (0.5M and 0.3M accordingly) simultaneously with rate 1mL/min into water–NH4OH solution at 20°C at a Ca/P molar ratio of 1.67 (corresponding to hydroxyapatite). The pH was maintained between 9 and 11 by discontinuous addition of concentrated aqueous NH3. The formed dispersion was continuously stirred and then aged at 20°C for 24h, then filtrated and washed several times with deionized water. HAp was dried at 110°C under vacuum [51]. One hundred milligram of the obtained calcium hydroxyapatite (Ca/P=1.57) was added to 50mL of Cu(CH3COO)2 solution (0.01M, pH=6). The suspension was stirred at 25°C for 74h. The obtained slurry was filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried overnight at 110°C. A greenish-blue powder was obtained. The content of Cu2+ ions in solution was detected by titration with EDTA (0.01M), indicator 1% PAN solution, before and after reaction with apatite. Analysis: HAp Ca/P=1.57±0.1, SSA=77.7±0.2m2/g; Cu–HAp Ca/P=1.57±0.1; SSA=77.3±0.2m2/g. IR HApcm−1: 3573νs OH, 3227νOH, 1655νOH2, 1460νCO3 2−, 1424νCO3 2−, 1089–1028ν3 PO4 3−, 962ν1 PO4 3−, 631νL OH, 601–561ν4 PO4 3−. IR Cu–HApcm−1: 3573νs OH, 3227νOH, 1655νOH2, 1460νCO3 2−, 1424νCO3 2−, 1089–1028ν3 PO4 3−, 966ν1 PO4 3−, 632νL OH, 604–565ν4 PO4 3−. 4.3 General procedure for homo-coupling of 1–8 alkynes Starting from alkynes 1–8 leads exclusively to the corresponding diynes 9–16 coupling compounds using the following conditions: The catalyst (60mg, 15mol%) is weighed into the flask, the solvent (6mL CH3CN) is added. The alkyne (0.4mmol) was dissolved in a small amount of solvent (CH3CN) and added to the mixture. The mixture is heated to reflux and air is bubbled through the solution. The reaction mixture was let to stir several hours (72h). After filtration, the crude product was purified by column chromatography and identified by 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra. 1H NMR: ν (CD2Cl2) 9: 7.39 (m, 4H), 7.37 (m, 6H). (CD3CN) 10: 7.45 (d, J =6.6Hz, 4H), 7.21 (d, J =6.6Hz, 4H), 2.40 (s, 6H). (CD3CN) 11: 7.51 (d, J =6.9Hz, 4H), 6.95 (d, J =6.9Hz, 4H), 3.84 (s, 6H). (CD2Cl2) 12: 7.36 (d, J =6.6Hz, 4H), 6.65 (d, J =6.6Hz, 4H), 3.01 (s, 12H). (CD2Cl2) 13: 7.51 (m, 4H), 7.08 (m, 6H). (CD2Cl2) 14: 7.67 (m). (CDCl3) 15: 2.05 (s, 2H), 1.51 (s, 12H). (CDCl3) 16: 1.91(m, 6H), 1.69 (m, 4H), 1.55 (m, 10H), 1.25 (m, 2H). 13C NMR: ν (CD2Cl2) 9: 133.5, 130.6, 129.4, 122.7, 82.5, 74.6 (CD2Cl2) 10: 140.9, 133.4, 130.3, 119.6, 82,5. 74.2, 22.4. (CD2Cl2) 11: 161.5, 135.0, 115.2, 114.6, 82.2, 73.7, 56.4 (CD2Cl2) 12: 151.6, 134.5, 112.7, 109.1, 83.3, 73.5, 40.9 (CD2Cl2) 13: 163.5 (d, J C–F=254Hz), 135.6 (d, J C–F=1.45Hz), 119.0, 116.8 (d, J C–F=39Hz), 81.4, 74.3 (CD2Cl2) 14: 133.9, 131.9 (q, J C–F=25Hz), 126.5, 126.3,124.8 (d, J C–F=284Hz), 81.9, 76.4. (CDCl3) 15: 84.1, 66.3, 65.5, 31.0. (CDCl3) 16: 83.0, 69.2, 68.3, 39.7, 25.0, 23.1. coredata.dc:description: The oxidative Glaser–Hay coupling reaction of terminal alkynes is a very important reaction in organic chemistry to achieve the synthesis of diyne compounds. In general the reaction is performed under homogeneous conditions using Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts in the presence of a reagent such as tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA), which can bind to copper ions, an organic base and dioxygen. Although this reaction is known for a long time, the mechanism is still under discussion. Pursuing our investigations on the use of apatites as catalysts for organic reactions we highlight in this work how it is possible to catalyze the Glaser–Hay reaction under heterogeneous conditions using a Cu-modified hydroxyapatite (Cu–HAp). With several para-substituted phenyl-acetylenes and alkynols we show that Cu–HAp acts as catalyst for CC coupling reactions leading to diyne derivatives in high yields without using auxiliary chelating molecules and organic bases. These heterogeneous conditions allow an easy recovery of the catalyst and simplify the purification work-up.
coredata.dc:title: Cu-modified hydroxy-apatite as catalyst for Glaser–Hay CC homo- coupling reaction of terminal alkynes
